description: Borrowed from French émulsion, from New Latin ēmulsiō, ēmulsiōnis, based on Latin ēmulgeō (“I milk out, extract”).

entries.meaning: A stable suspension of small droplets of one liquid in another with which it is immiscible.
examples: Mayonnaise is an emulsion where egg is used to keep oil and water mixed.

entries.meaning: (chemistry) A colloid in which both phases are liquid.
(photography) The coating of photosensitive silver halide grains in a thin gelatine layer on a photographic film.

verbs.description: emulsion (third-person singular simple present emulsions, present participle emulsioning, simple past and past participle emulsioned)
